title: Greensill Capital takes flagship fund fail in stride
text:
Greensill Capital, the supply chain financier founded by Financial Review Rich Lister Lex Greensill, nearly trebled net profits in calendar 2018 and is set to emulate that growth in 2019 despite a flagship fund for which it originated assets losing nearly all of its investors.

Greensill's $US49.4 million ($73 million) after-tax profit reported in financials lodged with the corporate regulator late Friday followed a $US20.8 million net profit in 2017, and came off revenue of $US273 million, which nearly doubled from 2017's $US138 million.

Greensill Capital founder Lex Greensill saw profits nearly trebled in 2018. Peter Braig

Greensill, which according to its founder is forecasting $600 million revenue in 2019, makes money by arranging traditional invoice factoring – paying a clients' invoice early for a discount, and recovering the whole amount from the debtor later – and payables factoring, where it finances an arrangement whereby debtors can have some suppliers paid early if they agree to a discount, while those that don't agree are often subject to extended repayment terms.

Greensill's strong 2018 result was recorded before a bumpy 2019 for the financier, which was set up in 2011 by Bundaberg farming family scion Mr Greensill, and was valued at $5 billion by a $1.15 billion funding injection from Japan's Softbank in May.

That support came as the first fund to be backed by Greensill-originated trade receivables, the GAM Greensill Supply Chain Finance Fund launched in 2016, lost nearly all of its assets under management during this year.
description: Huge growth in funds backed by trade receivables it has arranged is expected to inoculate the Australian financier from one high-profile hiccup.
